title: 112_hr3333
content: The "Foster Children Opportunity Act" requires state plans to have procedures to help alien children in the child welfare system achieve special immigrant juvenile status and lawful permanent resident status. The "Foster Children Opportunity Act" amends the Social Security Act to require state child welfare agencies to assist alien children in foster care in obtaining special immigrant juvenile status and other forms of relief under immigration law. The Social Security Act is amended to require state child welfare agencies to assist alien children in foster care to obtain special immigrant juvenile status or other relief under immigration law. The Social Security Act is amended to require state child welfare agencies to determine if filing petitions for special immigrant juvenile status or lawful permanent resident status for alien foster children is in the child's best interest in appropriate cases. AUTHORITY TO USE COURT IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM GRANT FUNDS TO EDUCATE AND TRAIN CHILD WELFARE AND COURT STAFF, INCLUDING JUDGES, SOCIAL WORKERS, COURT-APPOINTED SPECIAL ADVOCATES, AND LAWYERS TO ASSIST ALIEN CHILDREN IN ACHIEVING SPECIAL IMMIGRANT JUVENILE STATUS, LAWFUL PERMANENT RESIDENT STATUS, AND OTHER FORMS OF RELIEF UNDER IMMIGRATION LAW. Section 438(a)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to provide education and training for child welfare and court staff to assist alien children in obtaining special immigrant juvenile status, lawful permanent resident status, and other forms of relief under immigration law in a timely manner. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR CHILD WELFARE AGENCIES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide technical assistance to State child welfare agencies upon request, in consultation with other relevant departments. Grants and contracts may be awarded to qualified non-profit organizations for this purpose. SEC. 7. ELIGIBILITY FOR ASSISTANCE. The amendment to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 allows individuals with special immigrant juvenile status to be exempt from certain federal means-tested public benefits and other federal programs. The amendment exempts individuals with special immigrant juvenile status from specific federal programs and benefits. The amendment exempts individuals with special immigrant juvenile status from specific federal programs and benefits, including aid under the State plan approved under section 402 of the Act if the child would have been qualified to receive aid as a United States citizen. The effective date for the amendment is specified in Section 8. The amendments made by this Act, other than by section 7, will take effect on the date of enactment and apply to payments under part E of title IV of the Social Security Act for quarters starting on or after that date. If a State plan requires legislation to meet the new requirements, it will not be considered non-compliant solely for not meeting them before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the state legislature's session. The State legislature session ends after a 1-year period from the enactment of this Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session.
